abstract: pmc Invest Ophthalmol Vis Sci Invest Ophthalmol Vis Sci 1229 iovs IOVS Investigative Ophthalmology & Visual Science 0146-0404 1552-5783 Association for Research in Vision and Ophthalmology PMC12489862 PMC12489862.1 12489862 12489862 41025873 10.1167/iovs.66.12.70 IOVS-25-43682 1 Retinal Cell Biology Retinal Cell Biology Novel Role of Copper Transporter CTR1 and Therapeutic Potential of Copper Chelators in Retinal Ischemia-Reperfusion Injury Cu Transporter CTR1 and Ischemic Retinopathy Yamamoto Mai  1  2 Ash Dipankar  1  3  4 Sudhahar Varadarajan  1  4  5 Zaidi Syed Adeel H.  1  2  3 Rojas Modesto A.  1  2  5 Xu Zhimin  1  2 Kelley Spears Stephanie  1 Caldwell Ruth B.  1  2  6 Fukai Tohru  1  4  5 Ushio-Fukai Masuko  1  3 1 2 3 4 5 6 # mfukai@augusta.edu Tohru Fukai, Vascular Biology Center, Department of Pharmacology and Toxicology, Medical College of Georgia, at Augusta University, at Augusta University, 1460 Laney-Walker Blvd., Augusta, GA 30912, USA; tfukai@augusta.edu * MUF and TF contributed equally to this study and should be considered co-senior authors. 30 9 2025 9 2025 66 12 496268 70 04 9 2025 21 5 2025 30 09 2025 03 10 2025 03 10 2025 Copyright 2025 The Authors 2025 https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/ This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-NoDerivatives 4.0 International License. Purpose Retinal ischemia contributes to vision loss in ischemic and diabetic retinopathies through oxidative stress, neurovascular injury, and inflammation. Copper (Cu), whereas an essential micronutrient, can be toxic in excess and is regulated by Cu transporters such as CTR1. However, the role of CTR1 in ischemic retinopathy remains unclear. Methods and Results Retinal ischemia-reperfusion (IR) injury was induced by elevating intraocular pressure (IOP) to 110 millimeters of mercury (mm Hg) for 40 minutes in the right eyes of Ctr1 heterozygous (Ctr1 +/− +/− +/− O 2 - +/− Conclusions CTR1 plays a central role in mediating Cu-dependent oxidative stress, neurovascular degeneration, and inflammation following retinal IR injury. Targeting the CTR1–Cu axis may represent a novel therapeutic strategy for ischemic retinopathy. ischemic retinopathy copper (Cu) copper transporter oxidative stress neurovascular damage pmc-status-qastatus 0 pmc-status-live yes pmc-status-embargo no pmc-status-released yes pmc-prop-open-access yes pmc-prop-olf no pmc-prop-manuscript no pmc-prop-legally-suppressed no pmc-prop-has-pdf yes pmc-prop-has-supplement yes pmc-prop-pdf-only no pmc-prop-suppress-copyright no pmc-prop-is-real-version no pmc-prop-is-scanned-article no pmc-prop-preprint no pmc-prop-in-epmc yes Retinal ischemia is a major contributor of visual impairment and plays a key role in several retinal disorders, including glaucoma, diabetic retinopathy, age-related macular degeneration (AMD), and retinopathy of prematurity. 1 – 4 5 – 7 8 – 12 13 14 Copper (Cu) is an essential trace element that supports numerous physiological processes, including oxidative phosphorylation, iron metabolism, and the activity of Cu-dependent antioxidant enzymes. However, disruption of Cu homeostasis has been linked to various pathological conditions. 15 – 18 19 20 cuproptosis 21 18 , 22 We recently reported that Cu importer CTR1 expression are markedly increased in the hippocampus of a mouse model of Alzheimer's disease, as well as in brain endothelial cells (ECs) exposed to amyloid β42, which are associated with elevated Cu levels. 23 24 25 26 27 In this study, we demonstrate that the CTR1-Cu axis plays a critical role in promoting neurovascular injury and inflammation in response to retinal IR injury. Using Ctr1 +/− Materials and Methods Animal Study The use of mice was in accordance with the National Institutes of Health Guide for the Care and Use of Laboratory Animals and relevant ethical regulations. The animal protocol used in this study was approved by the institutional Animal Care committee and institutional Biosafety Committee of Augusta University. Mouse Retinal IR Injury Model and Tetrathiomolybdate Administration Both male and female Ctr1 +/− 24 14 , 28 – 30 Optical Coherence Tomography Mice were placed on the imaging platform of the Phoenix Micron III retinal imaging microscope, supplemented with an optical coherence tomography (OCT) imaging device (Phoenix Research Laboratories, Pleasanton, CA, USA). The eyes of mice were dilated with 1% tropicamide (Akron Pharmaceuticals, Lake Forest, IL, USA) and genteal gel was applied during imaging to keep the eye moist under ketamine/xylazine anesthesia. Retinal Thickness Measurement Retinal thickness was studied on retinal fresh frozen sections from mice on 7 days after the IR injury. Cross-sections with optic nerve attachment were prepared (7 µm) followed by hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) staining for morphological observation. Inner nuclear layer thicknesses at three different distances from the optic nerve head was determined using ImageJ software and averaged. Averaged retinal thickness was presented as a percentage compared with WT sham eyes. For this experiment, a total of nine WT mice, eight Ctr1 +/− Electroretinography for Visual Function A full scotopic electroretinogram (ERG) was recorded on day 7 post-IR, as previously described with some modification. 31 , 32 2 31 , 32 +/− Copper Measurements Cu contents were analyzed by inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) using a PlasmaQuad3, as reported previously. 23 Dihydroethidium Staining for Detection of Superoxide Dihydroethidium (DHE) staining was used to evaluate superoxide (O 2 − +/− Immunofluorescence Cryostat sections with a thickness of 7 to 12 µm were used for immunofluorescence staining. Fresh frozen sections were used for GFAP staining, whereas sections fixed in 4% paraformaldehyde (PFA) and embedded in optimal cutting temperature compound were used for Ctr1 and Iba1 staining. To prepare the 4% PFA-fixed optimal cutting temperature sections, eyes were fixed overnight in 4% PFA at 4°C. The following day, the eyeballs were thoroughly washed in phosphate-buffered saline (PBS) and then incubated in 15% and 30% sucrose at 4°C for 1 hour for cryoprotection. After sucrose infiltration, the tissues were snap frozen in optimal cutting temperature compound. The sections were blocked in 10% normal goat serum for 1 hour to prevent nonspecific binding. The sections were subsequently incubated with primary antibodies overnight at 4°C ( Table 1 +/− Table 1. List of Antibodies Used in IF and Western Blot Antibody Company Catalog No Dilution Anti-CTR1 Homemade IF (1:100) WB (1:500) Anti-NeuN Sigma-aldrich ABN78 IF (1:300) Anti-Iba1 Wako 019-19741 IF (1:250) Anti-GFAP BD pharmingen 556330 IF (1:50) Goat anti-rabbit IgG (H+L), Alexa fluor 488 Thermo fisher scientific A-11008 IF (1:500) Goat anti-mouse IgG (H+L), Alexa fluor 488 Thermo fisher scientific A-11001 IF (1:500) Goat anti-mouse IgG1, Alexa fluor 488 Thermo fisher scientific A-21121 IF (1:400) Anti-beta actin Santa cruz sc-47778 WB (1:1000) Anti-NF-κB p65 Cell signaling 8242 WB (1:1000) Anti-phospho-NF-κB p65 (Ser536) Cell signaling 3033 WB (1:1000) Goat anti-mouse IgG (H+L)-HRP conjugate Bio-rad 1721011 WB (1:2000) Goat anti-rabbit IgG (H + L)-HRP conjugate Bio-rad 1706515 WB (1:2000) IF, immunofluorescence; WB, western blot. Tdt-dUTP Terminal Nick-End Labeling Staining for Apoptosis The DNA fragmentation of apoptotic cells was analyzed by terminal dUTP TUNEL assay (In Situ Cell Death Detection Kit, Fluorescein; MilliporeSigma, Burlington, MA, USA) following the manufacturer's instructions. The assay measures the fragmented DNA of apoptotic cells by catalytically incorporating fluorescein-12-dUTP at the 3′-OH DNA ends using the enzyme terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase (TdT). Images were using a fluorescence microscope (Keyence, BZ-X700). For this experiment, a total of four WT mice, five Ctr1 +/− Evaluation of Neurodegeneration Using NeuN Staining Neuronal degeneration was assessed 7 days after IR injury, as described previously. 14 , 28 – 30 +/− +/− Retinal Vasculature Trypsin Digestion and Counting of Acellular Capillaries Eyeballs were isolated on day 14 after IR injury and fixed overnight in 4% PFA. The retinal vasculature was isolated by trypsin digestion as reported. 28 , 29 28 , 29 +/− Western Blot Analysis Retina protein extracts were prepared using RIPA buffer with added protease and phosphatase inhibitors. Protein (25–50 ug) were subjected to SDS-PAGE, transferred to nitrocellulose membranes, and blocked in 5% milk or 2% BSA. Membranes were incubated overnight at 4°C with primary antibodies (see Table 1 +/− Quantitative Real-Time PCR Total RNA was extracted from frozen retinal tissue using TRI Reagent (Molecular Research Center Inc., Cincinnati, OH, USA). Reverse transcription was carried out using the high-capacity cDNA reverse transcription kit (Applied Biosystems, Waltham, MA, USA) using 2 µg of total RNA. Quantitative PCR was performed with the SYBR Green PCR kit (Qiagen, Germantown, MD, USA) and ABI Prism 7000. The primer sequences for specific genes are shown in Table 2 +/− Table 2. Data are presented as mean ± SEM. Statistical tests were performed using Prism software version 9 (GraphPad Software, San Diego, CA, USA). Data were compared between groups of animals by a 2-tailed unpaired Student t n P P P Results CTR1 Expression and Cu Levels are Increased in the Retina After IR Injury To investigate the role of the Cu uptake transporter CTR1 in ischemic retinopathy, we utilized a mouse model of retinal IR injury. Mice were subjected to 40 minutes of ischemia on the right eye followed by reperfusion, whereas the left eye served as a sham control. 14 Fig. 1 Fig. 1 Fig. 1 Fig. 1 Supplementary Fig. S1 Figure 1. DHE staining demonstrated that TTM treatment markedly reduced O 2 - Fig. 8 +/− Figure 8.  Cu chelator TTM treatment attenuates oxidative stress following retinal IR i njury. A O 2 - n P P Scale bar B +/− Discussion Retinal IR injury is marked by oxidative stress, inflammation, neuronal loss, microvascular degeneration, and subsequent visual dysfunction; however, underlying molecular mechanisms remain unclear. Elevated Cu has been linked to retinal diseases, such as diabetic retinopathy and AMD, 19 , 20 15 25 , 41 +/− Degeneration of neurons in the GCL is a key feature of retinal injury following IR insult. 36 , 42 +/− 27 +/− 36 Glial activation is an early and critical event in retinal injury and has been closely linked to visual dysfunction in conditions such as IR injury, hypoxia, and diabetes. 43 , 44 43 , 45 +/− +/− Oxidative stress is a central driver of vascular degeneration, neuronal loss, and inflammation in the ischemic retina. Building on our prior work linking CTR1 to ROS production in brain microvascular ECs, 23 +/− 46 12 47 To assess the contribution of Cu to retinal IR pathology, we utilized the Cu chelator TTM in our retinal IR model. TTM is a small hydrophilic compound that chelates Cu with high specificity, which has been used in rodents and humans (for treatment of patients with Wilson disease who exhibit Cu toxicity and clinical trial for patients with cancer). 48 49 – 51 This study has several limitations. First, our temporal analysis of CTR1 expression and Cu levels was confined to the acute phase (up to 24 hours) after retinal IR injury. Although CTR1 expression was not elevated at days 2 and 7 post-injury, Cu levels were not examined at these later stages. Thus, we cannot rule out the possibility of delayed or secondary Cu elevation that could influence the chronic phase of retinal injury. Future studies including extended time points are needed to more fully define the temporal dynamics of CTR1-Cu signaling and their relationship to long-term retinal damage. Second, whereas our findings in Ctr1 +/− 52 In summary, our findings underscore the critical role of CTR1 and Cu in regulating oxidative stress, inflammation, and neurovascular degeneration during retinal IR injury, pointing to promising therapeutic opportunities. Cu chelation approaches, such as TTM treatment, may also hold potential for broader application in other ischemic and neurodegenerative disorders linked to oxidative stress and Cu imbalance. Future studies should evaluate the long-term impact of CTR1 modulation and Cu chelation on visual function and examine their possible synergy with current treatment strategies. Additionally, deeper investigation into the molecular pathways through which Cu interacts with other cellular signaling networks may further elucidate its role in retinal pathology. By identifying the CTR1-Cu axis as a viable therapeutic target, this work lays the groundwork for advancing novel treatments for ischemic retinal and neurovascular conditions.
